newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian minister leaves on landmark Cuba visit.
newsitem.headline: Canadian minister leaves on landmark Cuba visit.

text.p: Canadian Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy left on Tuesday for a visit to Cuba, underscoring Canada's independent policy towards the communist-ruled island.
A foreign affairs spokesman said Axworthy hoped to meet President Fidel Castro on Tuesday night and would have talks with other Cuban officials before leaving on Wednesday afternoon.
Canada has gone head-to-head with Washington over the U.S. Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to penalise some foreign companies doing business with Cuba.
Ottawa argues that the United States is improperly interfering in its affairs and says it pursues a policy of dialogue and engagement with countries like Cuba.
The United States, which has sought to isolate Cuba, has urged Canada and the European Union to press the Caribbean nation to promote democracy.
Commenting on the visit, U.S. Embassy spokesman Andrew Koss said: "We've pressed Canada to be more vocal in its opposition to the Castro regime and promote democracy and human rights on the island.
"It is our hope that Foreign Minister Axworthy's visit will reinforce this message."
Axworthy said before departing that human rights would be among the topics he would discuss.
He will be the highest ranking Canadian to visit Cuba since former prime minister Pierre Trudeau went there in 1976.
